User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the LedgerBalance application.

googleId.description: User's Google ID (if using Google login).

Book.title: Book
Book.description: Represents a financial book (ledger) owned by a user.

Account.title: Account
Account.description: Represents a financial account (e.g., Cash, Bank, Accounts Receivable).

category.description: Category of the account (e.g., Asset, Liability, Equity, Revenue, Expense).

TransactionEntry.title: TransactionEntry
TransactionEntry.description: Represents a single entry (debit or credit) within a transaction.

id.description: Unique identifier for the transaction entry.

amount.description: Amount of the entry (debit or credit).

type.description: Type of the entry (Debit or Credit).

Category.title: Category
Category.description: Represents a category for grouping accounts (e.g., Cash, Capital, Party).

Note.title: Note
Note.description: Represents a single note or to-do item for a book.

isCompleted.description: Whether the note is completed (for checklists).

createdAt.description: The date and time the note was created.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to support a double-entry accounting application (LedgerBalance) with a focus on user-owned data and clear authorization. User data is stored under `/users/{userId}`.  Books, which represent ledgers, are stored under `/users/{userId}/books/{bookId}`, establishing a clear ownership hierarchy. Transactions, Accounts, TransactionEntries and Categories all follow a similar hierarchical structure, residing as subcollections of `/users/{userId}/books/{bookId}`. A new `notes` collection has been added under books to store user-specific notes that can sync across devices. This structure enables path-based security rules based on user ID. This provides Authorization Independence as access control is implied by the document path. QAPs are supported through structural segregation based on user ownership.
